work.p: Phrases from this manuscript are similar to words that appear in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in the poem that would be titled "Song of Myself." See "the clover and timothy" (1855, p. 18); "Over the western persimmon. . . . over the longleaved corn and the delicate blue-flowered flax; / Over the white and brown buckwheat, a hummer and a buzzer there with the rest" (1855, p. 36).

A phrase from this manuscript is similar to a line that appears in the poem "Come Up From the Fields Father," which was first published in the 1867 edition of Leaves of Grass: "Smell you the buckwheat, where the bees were lately buzzing?" (1867, p. 39).

titleStmt.title: Of this broad and majestic
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman

Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: A phrase from this manuscript appears, slightly altered, in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, in the poem that would later be titled "Song of Myself." The manuscript was therefore probably written before or early in 1855.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Of this broad and majestic
bibl.orgName: The Oscar Lion Papers, 1914–1955, New York Public Library, New York, N.Y.
bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
Written on the back of this leaf are several poetic lines. A phrase from one of them appeared in the poem ultimately titled "I Sing the Body Electric."

body.p: Of all that there is in the this broad and majestic universe, you can mention nothing either all in the visible world, or and much in the greater world invisible, that is not but what is owned by the Poet.—He owns the solid ground and tills it and reaps from every field and harvests fro the cotton and grain, dried grass. the timothy and the clovers.—.—All the woods and all the orchards—the corn, with its ear and stalks and tassels—the buckwheat with and its sweet white blossoms tops where and the bees that hum there all day—
